bboxes.raw_text:
WASHINGTON Three of the
countrys most celebrated mu-
sicians expressed support for
drive to obtain pledges from con-
cert artists against playing to
segregated audiences in the
South.


They are Vladimir Horowitz,
the pianist; Leonard Bernstein,
conductor of the New York Phil
harmonic, and Erich Leinsdort,
music director Of the Boston
Symphony Orchestra.


A new protest against the bar
ring of Negroes from concert
halls was recently launched by the
National Association Of Colored
People, the Congress of Racial
Equality and the Student Non
violent Coordinating Committee.


The NAACP last week appealed
to some 90 prominent musicians
to form committee and plan
new measures that might help

make cultural events equally &C
cessible to Negroes in southern
cities. An immediate objective
would be to have musicians re-
fuse to play in segregated con-
cert halls.


Horowitz, in an interview, said
he fully agreed with his colleague
Arthur Rubinstein, in the con-
viction that the artist has an
important place in the fight
against discrimination.


GAS representatives ofthe fine
arts" the Russian-born pianist
asserted, 1--WE have a special
obligation in a democratic So
ciety to set an example by striv-
ing for human dignity and indie
pendence."


"The time is long overdue"
the New York conductor declared,
"for steps to bring equal cultural
as we'll as political opportuni-
ties to all Americans.

Noted Concert Artists


To Shun Segregated Audiences

ATLANTA = A Negro demon
stration at truck-stop restau-
rant turned into a stone and bot
tie throwing battle between whites
and Negroes.


Police arrested II Negroes and
charged them with violating
Georgia's antitrespass law and
with disorderly conduct.


One policeman, 1t. H.L.Oa I.
was injured slightly when a bot
tie struck his leg.


H. H. Daniels, operator of the
restaurant. said Negroes have
been picketing his establishment
since last week.

CLEVELAND. Ohio A local
chapter of the National Associa-
tion for the Advancement of Col
ored People picketed the Plain
Dealer and called for a two
week boycott of the newspaper in
a disagreement with its editorial
policy.

The family of Mrs. j. Anderson Morrison honored
Phoenix Urban Leagues outstanding family year.
made last Friday the annual meeting of the held
Safari Hotel in Scousdale.


Mrs. Morrison and her husband worked
agricultural aborers their family Three
graduated from Arizona University in her senior


Seated from left Mrs. Morrison the mother and
Carolina, 1921 E. Wood St.


Standing Misses Fleta Hill, Doris HILL Dimple Morrison
Darlene Hill and Mrs. Velner Nelson Of Los Angeles.


Mrs. Nelson completing senior ASU
her student teaching Sheraton Park School.


Three daughters teach
Gray of Sacramento, Calf. was unable to attend

Milk from l.3 million COWS is
needed to meet the continuing
demand for ice cream in the
US. Zach person eats is III
quarts year).

Mr.. and Mrs. Leon McCarty,
2434 w. Adams, are the proud
parents of wee girl born on
March 18th.
